reply_context.text:
I found that this is wrong. Democracy actually is a powerful motivating force for a critical slice of the population *if they perceive a real threat*.

I call this the "legibility" theory of democratic backsliding: the more legible the threat, the more likely it is to prompt effective pushback.

for one thing: it empowers you to make better decisions even when it might not have occurred to you to involve an LLM. For example, most people don't know that a single queue with N servers is faster than N single-server queues. My knowledge of complexity helps me find the shortest checkout line.

reply_context.text: This isn't really about LLMs specifically, it's about how much information we volunteer about ourselves and how few details it takes to deanonymize people. Information extraction was a thing long before LLM hit the scene, they just make it a lot easier.

posts.text:
A lot of people, including me, were wondering how an IRB could ever approve this study. 

The answer is that no IRB did. The person who ‚Äúsigned off‚Äù on approval from the only ethics board that reviewed it had resigned three years earlier. His signature was used without his knowledge.
As it was before, so it is now and will be forevermore: the real art underlying CS is learning how to manage complexity.

posts.text: I think the clearest way is actually to introduce them to spectral methods more generally. take a movie review dataset, apply SVD, then truncate to the top singular vectors: your representational space will naturally generate the dominant movie genres.
